articles.headline: At Walgreen, Renouncing Corporate Citizenship
articles.snippet: The Walgreen chief executive, who said he was “proud of our Illinois heritage,” is considering a merger that would move the company’s headquarters to Switzerland in a bid to decrease its tax bill.
articles.abstract: The Walgreen chief executive, who said he was “proud of our Illinois heritage,” is considering a merger that would move the company’s headquarters to Switzerland in a bid to decrease its tax bill.
articles.lead_paragraph: A little less than two years ago, Gregory D. Wasson, the chief executive of Walgreen, sought a series of tax breaks from Illinois, where his company is based.

articles.headline: UnitedHealth, an Insurer Switching Roles, Helps Hospitals on Medicare Billing
articles.snippet: Executive Health Resources, a consultant owned by UnitedHealth Group, assists hospitals with winning larger payments from Medicare.
articles.abstract: Executive Health Resources, a consultant owned by UnitedHealth Group, assists hospitals with winning larger payments from Medicare.
articles.lead_paragraph: To hospitals, billions of dollars depend on how they define a patient’s stay.

articles.headline: Russian Hackers Targeting Oil and Gas Companies
articles.snippet: The intrusions give the hackers the opportunity to seize control of industrial control systems from afar, much as the United States and Israel did of Iran’s centrifuges in 2009.
articles.abstract: The intrusions give the hackers the opportunity to seize control of industrial control systems from afar, much as the United States and Israel did of Iran’s centrifuges in 2009.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Russian hackers have been systematically targeting hundreds of Western oil and gas companies, as well as energy investment firms, according to private cybersecurity researchers.

articles.headline: A Conduit for Russian Gas, Tangled in Europe’s Conflicts
articles.snippet: Work on a major pipeline beneath the Black Sea has stopped, as the European Union and the United States apply pressure on Bulgaria, where the gas conduit was to make landfall.
articles.abstract: Work on a major pipeline beneath the Black Sea has stopped, as the European Union and the United States apply pressure on Bulgaria, where the gas conduit was to make landfall.
articles.lead_paragraph: The port of Varna on the Bulgarian Black Sea coast was supposed to be the gateway for a major new pipeline, directly connecting Europe to Russia’s vast natural gas supplies. Now the project has stalled, as Bulgaria finds itself torn between the European Union and Russia in the escalating conflict over Ukraine.

articles.headline: For Iraq, Potential Leader With a Tarnished Past
articles.snippet: Ahmad Chalabi, once championed by the Bush administration as a possible leader for Iraq and then pushed aside for faulty depictions of weapons of mass destruction, has re-emerged in talks among the country’s political parties as a contender for pr...
articles.abstract: Ahmad Chalabi, once championed by the Bush administration as a possible leader for Iraq and then pushed aside for faulty depictions of weapons of mass destruction, has re-emerged in talks among the country’s political parties as a contender for prime minister.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — He took millions of dollars from the C.I.A., founded and was accused of defrauding the second-biggest bank in Jordan and sold the Bush administration a bill of goods on weapons of mass destruction in Iraq.

articles.headline: A Grieving Father Pulls a Thread That Unravels BNP’s Illegal Deals
articles.snippet: A long investigation into some of the world’s top banks, which started with a father from New Jersey, reached a peak with a guilty plea from BNP Paribas.
articles.abstract: A long investigation into some of the world’s top banks, which started with a father from New Jersey, reached a peak with a guilty plea from BNP Paribas.
articles.lead_paragraph: A bus bombing two decades ago — and a New Jersey father’s quest for justice — inadvertently set off a chain of events that led American prosecutors to accuse some of the world’s biggest banks of transferring money for nations like Iran.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: A Ruling That Both Sides Can Run With
articles.snippet: Even as conservatives celebrated coming out on the winning side of a divisive social issue, their court victory may have also handed Democrats an issue that will turn out liberal voters.
articles.abstract: Even as conservatives celebrated coming out on the winning side of a divisive social issue, their court victory may have also handed Democrats an issue that will turn out liberal voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court’s ruling on Monday that the government cannot force certain employers to pay for birth control was more than a rebuke to President Obama. It was vindication of the conservative movement’s efforts to chip away at laws it finds objectionable by raising questions of freedom of expression.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Michael D. Shear

articles.headline: Japan Announces a Military Shift to Thwart China
articles.snippet: The Japanese prime minister announced that his government would reinterpret the antiwar Constitution to allow the armed forces to come to the aid of friendly nations.
articles.abstract: The Japanese prime minister announced that his government would reinterpret the antiwar Constitution to allow the armed forces to come to the aid of friendly nations.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Japan’s prime minister announced a reinterpretation of the country’s pacifist Constitution on Tuesday, freeing its military for the first time in over 60 years to play a more assertive role in the increasingly tense region.
articles.byline: By Martin Fackler and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: G.M. Sales Rise as Buyers Ignore Recalls
articles.snippet: The automaker reported a rare bit of good news on Tuesday, with sales up 1 percent, and said its annual selling rate remained in line with its forecast.
articles.abstract: The automaker reported a rare bit of good news on Tuesday, with sales up 1 percent, and said its annual selling rate remained in line with its forecast.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has been a mystery in the auto industry in recent months: How can General Motors, embroiled in a safety crisis that has led to the recall of about 29 million vehicles worldwide this year, continue to have such strong sales?
